Award.AwardTitle: Borrowed Power: War Finance and the Resort to Arms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
When Louis XII contemplated the invasion of Milan in 1499, the exile Trivulzio pointed that out for success in war, "three things are necessary: money; more money; and still more money." If that statement was true then, it is even more the case in modern times with the extraordinarily, expensive upkeep of a capable military. The method of war finance affects when and how wars are fought, and on what terms they are settled. Yet most theories of international conflict are oddly divorced from this. The most widespread explanations assume that the distribution of power - the very thing that is affected by finance - is fixed or that its dynamics are outside the control of the actors. Even recent theorites that do allow actors to alter the distribution of power do not examine how their efforts are funded. This project is one of the first to examine how the form of finance can affect the initiation, duration, and outcome of war. As shown in preliminary work, features specific to sovereign debt cobine to change the dynamics of bargaining over peace terms in a way that wars, once begun, can last longer and be harder to settle. War finance is not an innocuous aspect of war, but should be regarded as an important cause of both settlement and protracted conflict. This project aims to generalize a game-theoretic model that can be used to study interactions between resource-poor actors with access to foreign financial markets, the effects of financial and political systems that determine the costs of government debt, and the methods of attracting lendors, both domestic and foreign. Hypotheses derived from this model will then be used to to test hypotheses concerning the factors mentioned above. Besides generating the model and its implications, a data set will be created concerning debt financing for countries from 1815 to the present. This dataset will be used to test the model and will also be made available to other scholars who might be studying similar topics. The reuslts of this research will aslo be made available to policy makers who are interested in issues of national security.

The study of war finance, especially of how governments raise revenue to fund their military expenses and how this affects their military efforts, is likely to be of interest to political scientists in general, but also to economists and sociologists who have been interested in how war shapes the political economy of a state but rarely raised the questions addressed in this project. The projects is also the next step in the development of modern theories of war which have endogenized the distribution of power. The impact of the project is potentially transformative because the project suggests the causation mechanism can not be studied in isolation from financial structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigates how the mobilization of resources that determine a government's military capabilities affect the internal stability of nations and the prospects for conflict and peace among them.

Whereas it is well-known that most interstate wars are funded by borrowing (and less so by taxation), we had not examined whether the method of finance has an impact on the likelihood that war will occur or an existing war prolonged. This project shows that if mobilization is paid for with debt, the incentives to negotiate peacefully are weakened, and mutually-acceptable settlements available with finance-by-taxation would no longer exist. This is because debt repayment is conditional on the outcome, making debt service relatively more costly if fighting does not occur (because they it must certainly occur). It further shows that mobilization efficiency (how nations convert resources into military capabilities) is crucial in understanding how strong these incentives are. The results suggest that to understand why wars occur, we need to pay closer attention to the costs of the peace that is supposed to avoid them.

Many theories take it us unproblematic that investing in the military translates into military effectiveness. However, in many non-democratic countries the military is also a potential threat to the regime itself, which confronts it with a dilemma: should it make the military powerful enough to deal with external threats or weaken it to render it less of a threat to the government? It is commonly argued that to avoid coup d'etas, authoritarian rulers appoint incompetent but loyal generals. This project investigated the logic of this claim and has found it unsound. It shows that rulers always prefer to hire the most competent generals they can find (and that they would tend to recruit them from a privileged stratum in society), and that they balance the threat posed by the armed forces by manipulating the resources available to them. The dilemma is always resolved in favor of internal stability (rulers prefer slightly weaker forces that would not threaten them) if the extent of the external threat is commonly known. If the ruler and the army disagree on the seriousness of the threat, then the ruler is in terrible shape: the optimal strategy can sometimes leave the regime with military forces that are simultaneously too weak to confront the external threat and strong enough to challenge the ruler. The project suggests that the fundamental problem in civil-military relations arises from divergent threat assessments and incentives not to reveal them in a timely fashion. The results further imply that foreign relations with such rulers can be very combustible: they have incentives to behave more aggressively internationally to induce loyalty domestically, and their armies are unlikely to be led by incompetents.

Both parts of the project described above took it as granted that the ruler will have access to resources and that the matter was reduced to what resources to use, how much to give, and to whom. Most government revenue, however, is collected through semi-voluntaristic means; taxes being the prime example. For most of history rulers had only vague ideas about the wealth of the taxpayers, and so had no reliable means of determining what level of taxation would be acceptable. If taxes were set too low, everyone would pay them but the government would fail to raise enough revenue for important undertakings. If taxes were set too high, few would pay them and some might resort to violent resistance. This project shows that despite the ruler's edge in coercive power, the fact that wealth assessments are uncertain (and rely mostly on self-reporting) leaves the ruler in a very weak position. Depending on what the ruler believes the wealth of the taxpayers is, the tax could end up being very low, which everyone pays and no information about wealth is revealed; it could be intermediate, which causes the poor to revolt occasionally but leaves the elites willing to pay in exchnage for exemptions and other tax privileges; or it could be very high, which causes the elites to sometimes join with the poor in rebellion against the government. In each of these cases, the ruler is worse off because the taxes collected are lower and the risk of resistance is higher than if wealth were known. The results suggest that the rise of modern states has little to do with the government's increasing ability to coerce its citizens or bribe them by providing public goods. Instead it is caused by improving administrative capacity that allows it to assess wealth better. This conclusion has direct implications for strategies to deal with failed and post-conflict states where administrative infrastructure is largely non-existent.

Aside from opening new venues for research in political science and economics, the project's implications are of direct relevance to US foreign policy, as noted above.
